skuid__text.contents:
Welcome to Skuid! 

This wizard will walk you through the typical process for building your applications, from start to finish.

We'll introduce the basics of app building and where to learn more about building with Skuid. Think of this as a quick overview of what things are, where to find them, and how to use them rather than a drill down into each step.

After completing the wizard, create your own application, explore the samples we've created for you, or read our related resources to learn more.

action.label: If user canceled installation, don't prompt it again

skuid__text.contents:
Your first step in building great apps is almost always creating a Skuid data source.

A data source represents a connection to a single external system. They are created based on data source types—which provide the code Skuid needs to connect to the selected system.

You'll create a data source for each external system you want to connect to. If you need to authenticate your connection—prove to a system that you have rights to access it—you can also set up an authentication provider.

Style your apps using the Design System Studio to create design systems, instead of managing complicated CSS files.

Design systems are made up of variables and style variants. Variables are individual attributes—height, width, color, spacing—that can be reused across component style options. Style variants are created per component, allowing for unique, fully-customized design variations.

After creating your variables and style variants, you can save your design system and use it across the pages of your app.

The next step in developing an all-star application is creating the app !

An app is a collection of Skuid pages and their associated URLs. Once created, apps are used to specify user access and deployment features{{#$Model.FeatureFlags.data.0.nativeEnabled}}—such as native mobile packages{{/$Model.FeatureFlags.data.0.nativeEnabled}}. It's the final step in organizing the pages of an application for your users. 

Each page within your app must be assigned a route—a URL where end users can access the page. Routes should help end users identify where they are within an application.

You can have few or many apps, and they can be as small or as complex as you need.

It's time to make your app available to your users. This is known as deployment.

After that, you'll need to make sure your {{^$Model.FeatureFlags.data.0.appPermSetsEnabled}}profiles{{/$Model.FeatureFlags.data.0.appPermSetsEnabled}}{{#$Model.FeatureFlags.data.0.appPermSetsEnabled}}site permission sets{{/$Model.FeatureFlags.data.0.appPermSetsEnabled}} are granted access to the app and any data source used within the app. 

Now's the time to import (or create) your users, if you haven't already! Be sure to assign the new or imported users to a {{^$Model.FeatureFlags.data.0.appPermSetsEnabled}}profile{{/$Model.FeatureFlags.data.0.appPermSetsEnabled}}{{#$Model.FeatureFlags.data.0.appPermSetsEnabled}}site permission set{{/$Model.FeatureFlags.data.0.appPermSetsEnabled}} with access permissions to the apps they need.

And with that, you’ve completed the tour! 

The goal was to help you identify what you need to learn more about—and where to explore. But if you’re not ready to build your own apps from start-to-finish, don’t worry.
Try exploring our sample app by clicking the links below:

After you've explored the sample app, it's time to try creating your own.

For more information about the steps we've covered in this tour, try the resources below:

•  Data overview
•  Creating a datasource
•  Authentication options

•  App Composer overview
•  Pages overview
•  Components overview

•  Basics of app creation
•  {{^$Model.FeatureFlags.data.0.appPermSetsEnabled}}Profile assignments {{/$Model.FeatureFlags.data.0.appPermSetsEnabled}}{{#$Model.FeatureFlags.data.0.appPermSetsEnabled}}Site permission set assignments{{/$Model.FeatureFlags.data.0.appPermSetsEnabled}}
In-depth lessons about the Skuid process—from the basic concepts of Skuid to building an application.
Join our community to get answers to your questions, offer suggestions, and report problems.
Learn about Skuid features and their properties in our reference documentation.
